STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 19, 2020
Nicole Gillies
Youth Guidance Foster Care
70 Calhoun Street
Battle Creek, MI 49017
RE: License #: CB130201519
Youth Guidance Foster Care
70 Calhoun Street
Battle Creek, MI 49017
Dear Ms. Gillies:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
May 8, 2020. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract
and Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or ISEP section
citation, e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
322 E. Stockbridge Ave
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
(269) 251-2471
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB130201519
Licensee Name: Youth Guidance Foster Care
Licensee Address: 70 Calhoun St.
Battle Creek, MI 49017
Licensee Telephone #: (269) 969-9438
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Nicole Gillies, Designee
Name of Facility: Youth Guidance Foster Care
Facility Address: 70 Calhoun Street
Battle Creek, MI 49017
Facility Telephone #: (269) 969-9438
Original Issuance Date: 06/01/1992
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

Date of On-site Inspection(s): 05/08/2020

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(1) An agency shall conduct an annual on-site visit and
complete a written reevaluation of a foster home.
Three of three open foster home files reviewed which required a renewal home
study during this period under review (PUR) did not have a complete written
reevaluation of the foster home. All three reports did not provide information on
when the emergency procedures were conducted as required and two reports did
not provide specific information on the location of the ammunition in the home. One
report does not provide specific information about safety equipment for a hot tub and
only references this equipment as “available if needed”. One report states that the
foster child reported that the caregiver gives her “whopping”, but it is never followed
up on within the report.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Two of three open foster home files reviewed and requiring a renewal home study
during this PUR did not have documentation that the home study report was
provided to the department at least 15 days prior to the license expiring. The first
renewal report was completed one day prior to the license expiring and the second
renewal report was completed eleven days prior to the license expiring.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(1) An agency shall recommend to the department the
appropriate licensing action consistent with facts contained in
the foster home evaluation and any special evaluations.
4

Three of three open foster care home files reviewed had a recommendation for
renewal even though the renewal report was incomplete and because the report was
incomplete, the homes were not in compliance. This involved the lack of quarterly
emergency procedures documented and not addressing the foster child’s report of
whopping.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(a) Prior approval from the certifying agency authorizing the
placement of a child in the home.
One of three Borrowed home files reviewed did not have documentation that an
agreement was reached prior to placement of the child in the home. The child was
placed on 3/6/20 and the agreement was documented as occurring on 3/13/20.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019, 2018 licensing renewal inspection for which
a CAP was approved on 8/18/2018 and the 2017 licensing interim inspection
report with an approved CAP dated 7/21/2017.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary
collateral contacts.
One of two Special Evaluations reviewed during this PUR did not have a thorough
investigation documented in the Special Evaluation Report (SER). This report
documented for the second time that the child reported receiving “whopping” from
the caregiver. Documentation shows that there was very little follow up during the
investigation other than to document that the caregiver reported not “whopping” the
child. The home was found in compliance just on the word of the caregiver with no
further collateral contacts.
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
5

Three of three Independent Living case files reviewed did not have documentation
that the agency provided a copy of their program statement to the youth.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
Three of three Independent Living case files reviewed did not have documentation
that the agency provided a copy of their policy and procedures to the youth.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
independent living as the most appropriate placement for the
youth.
Two of three Independent Living case files reviewed did not have documentation of
the agency documenting the rational for the selection of Independent Living as the
most appropriate placement for the youth.
R 400.12507 Medical/dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living
receives any needed medical, dental, and mental health care as
required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental, and mental health
care provided shall be documented in the youth's record.
One of three Independent Living case files reviewed did not have documentation
that the youth’s medical/dental and mental health care was being provided as
required. This involved the following: last medical exam is documented as taking
place on 10/11/18 with a routine illness on 10/19/18, dental is documented as taking
place on 1/22/19 and the 1295 for June 2019 states “needs well child exam” but no
documentation this was completed. This youth is on Psychotropic medication and
the only medical passports present during this PUR occurred on 12/18/19 to 1/29/20.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
6

Two of three Independent Living case files reviewed did not have documentation of
the Independent Living Contract being developed as required.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of three Independent Living case files reviewed did not have documentation of
the Independent Living Contract being updated every 90-calandar days.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
(3) The report shall be an assessment of all of the following:
(d) Three current references from persons not related to the
applicants. There shall be an evaluation of any negative
references.
One of three Adoptive family evaluation case files reviewed was missing the
signature and date of one of the three required references.
R 400.12505 Supervision
(1) An agency shall provide supervision for a youth in independent
living consistent with the youth's need for supervision, as required
by R 400.12504(2) (e).
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying with the
terms of the contract required by R 400.125010, continues to
reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and is managing
expenditures
Two of three open independent living case files reviewed did not have
documentation of the DHHS-1295 being completed for each home visit.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements.
7

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Placement exception request (PER)
FOM 722.03-
page 14-16
Was a PER completed when required and completed quarterly.
A placement must not be made if it will result in one of the
following:
• More than three foster children in that foster home.
• More than six total children, including the foster family’s birth
and/or adopted children.
• Siblings placed apart; see Placement of Sibling Groups in this
item.
One of three open foster care case files reviewed which required two PERs, one for
number of children in the home and the second for sibling placed apart did not have
the PER completed. Both PERs were documented as “still in progress”.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019 and the 2018 licensing renewal inspection for
which a CAP was approved on 8/18/2018.
DHHS Policy - Supervisory Approval USP
FOM 722-09 -
Page 27
The caseworker’s supervisor must review, approve, and sign
the updated service plan within fourteen days, after a face to
face meeting with the caseworker.
One of three Open foster care case files reviewed did not have the supervisory
approval completed within the required 14-day time limit. This report had the
approval one day outside of the 14-day time limit. This was only one of sixteen
Update Service Plans reviewed.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019.
DHHS Policy CASEWORKER CONTACT CHILD IN OUT-OF-HOME
FOM 722-06H - PLACEMENT:
Page 5
The first face-to-face contact with the child must take place
within five business days from the date the case is assigned to
the caseworker or within five business days of the date of the
placement move. At least one contact each month must take
place at the child’s placement location.
8

One of three open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the agency provided the appropriate caseworker contact with the youth. This
involved the assignment of the case on 1/7/20 and the first worker contact
documented as 2/4/20.
Two of three open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have
documentation of monthly caseworker contacts with the youth in their placements.
This involved no documented home visit for a youth in July 2019 and another youth
in April 2020.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019, 2018 licensing renewal inspection for which
a CAP was approved on 8/18/2018 and the 2017 licensing interim inspection
report with an approved CAP dated 7/21/2017.
DHHS Policy - OVERVIEW and QUALITY VISIT STANDARDS
FOM 722-06H
Page 1-3
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been
found to produce positive outcomes for children in foster care. A
quality visit is defined as one in which the caseworker:
- Meets with each child individually without the presence of
other individuals to give the child an opportunity to ask
questions.
- Assesses each child’s needs and takes appropriate action or
offers services in response to the identified need of each child.
- Shows interest in the individual child to build trust and
establish rapport.
- Shares and explains the case plan in a developmentally
appropriate way while allowing the child to ask questions and
express viewpoints.
One of three open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation of a
quality visit for each home visit documented in the file. This involved one of ten
home visits in this specific case file.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019 and the 2018 licensing renewal inspection for
which a CAP was approved on 8/18/2018.
DHHS Policy TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
FOM 722-06H p
15
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within
five business days of the contact.
9

Three of three Open foster care case files reviewed did not have each caseworker
contact for a home visit entered into the MiSACWIS system within the required five
days. This involved twenty-two of twenty-eight entered timely for a seventy-nine
percent compliance rate.
DHHS Policy Foster care action summary requirements
FOM 722-03
Page 18
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a
case.
All foster care cases where there is:
1. A replacement.
2. Termination from foster care placement.
3. A change in FC worker.
4. Agency change/transfer to another FC agency (if less than 30
days of completion of last case service plan).
5. A change in the parent's living situation.
6. Case closing (if less than 30 days of completion of last case
service plan).
7. Foster care transfer to adoption.
One of three open foster care case files reviewed had one placement change
documented with a DHHS-69 which was completed on 6/6/19 and had an effective
date of 5/10/19.
One of two closed foster care case files had a closing DHHS-69 without a
completion date documented on the form.
Three of three open Independent Living case files reviewed had action documented
in the file but the DHHS-69s were not documented as being completed. This
involved five placement changes with missing DHHS-69s.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019 and the 2018 licensing renewal inspection for
which a CAP was approved on 8/18/2018.
DHHS Policy - Required Participation in Development
FOM 722-08C -
Page 2
The foster parent/caregiver must be included in the PATP
process. The foster parent/caregiver signature is required and
indicates that the foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and
agrees to the activities required to meet the needs of the child in
their care. Parents and youths age 14 and older must sign the
PATP. If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
PATP, foster care workers must identify, and document
10

additional action needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the PATP.
One of three open foster care case files reviewed did not have all of the required
signatures documented in the file. This involved a biological father’s signature
missing from three Parent Agency Treatment Plans (PATP).
One of three Independent Living case files reviewed did not have caregivers’
signature on an Updated Service Plan prior to the youth moving to Independent
Living. This occurred during the PUR of this inspection.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019
DHHS Policy - CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH PARENT(S)
FOM 722-06H -
Page 10
The caseworker must have face-to-face contact with each
parent/guardian at least once each calendar month, with at least
one contact in each quarter occurring in the parent’s place of
residence.
One of three open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the caseworker visited the parents at their residence each quarter. There was no
documentation of any visits to the parental residence.
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings.
722-6B page 2-6
Type Time Frame
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Two of three open independent living case files reviewed did not have
documentation that the Family Team Meeting (FTM) took place as required. This
involved the first FTM taking place on 7/18/19 which is beyond the thirty-day time
frame for the USP that ended on 8/21/19. The second involved an FTM taking place
on 6/5/19 for an USP that ended on 8/19/19. Again, beyond the thirty-day time
frame.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019 and the 2018 licensing renewal inspection for
which a CAP was approved on 8/18/2018.
DHHS Policy INDEPENDENT LIVING PREPARATION
FOM 722-03C –
page 1-3
The Parent Agency Treatment Plan for each youth age 14 or
older must contain a written description of the programs and
11

services which will help the youth take care of oneself
physically, socially, economically and psychologically. Examples
of age appropriate services include, but are not limited to:
• Daily living skills.
• Preventive health services.
• Educational support.
• Employment services.
• Housing education/assistance.
• Mentoring - a youth must be connected to an adult who will
guide and support him/her as a parent would after his/her case
is closed.
Independent living preparation skills are assessed for each
youth as being adequate or inadequate on the Child
Assessment of Needs and Strengths; see FOM 722-08B, Foster
Care - Child (Re) Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
Assessment and Preparation of Youth
Assess independent living skills for each youth as being
adequate or inadequate based on the Child Assessment of
Needs and Strengths and the Ansell-Casey Life Skills
Assessment. Provision of independent living services must be
documented within the Parent-Agency Treatment Plan.
Two of three open independent living case files reviewed did not have
documentation of the agency preparing the youth for independent living.
DHHS Policy Permanency Pact
FOM 722-07F
page 8-9
The Permanency Pact is a free tool created by Foster Club that
is designed to encourage life-long, kin-like connections between
a young person and a supportive adult.
Review the Permanency Pact with the youth and the
supportive adult(s)/relative caregiver.
Complete the Permanency Pact Certificate with the youth and
supportive adult(s)/relative caregiver.
Provide a copy to each participant, upload a copy to the
Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS, and include the original
agreement in the permanency plan approval packet.
• DHS-347, Permanency Goal Approval.
The assigned caseworker must complete this form.
Upload a copy to the Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS and
attach the original as the cover sheet to the permanency plan
approval packet.
• Independent Living Plan, if applicable.
Note: If independent living will be the youth's living
arrangement, then a detailed independent living plan must be
submitted with the permanency goal approval packet; see FOM
12

722-03C, Preparation and Placement of Older Youth, for
detailed information on independent living plans.
Two of three Open independent living case files reviewed did not have
documentation of the Permanency Pact being developed.
DHHS Policy - Medicaid Card & DHHS-3762:
FOM 801 - Page
18
Each child in care must be enrolled in Medicaid (MA) and have
an assigned MA recipient ID number to ensure prompt health
services for foster children at the time of placement. The foster
care provider is given the DHS-3762, Consent to Routine, Non-
Surgical Medical Care and Emergency Medical/Surgical
Treatment card, which allows the provider to take the child to
the doctor and respond to emergencies.
One of three open independent living case files reviewed in which the youth was in
foster care during part of the PUR did not have documentation that the caregiver
was provided the DHHS-3762 at time of placement. Documentation indicates that
the DHHS-3762 was provided four days after placement.
DHHS Policy Denial of MCI Consent to Adopt a Specific Child
ADM 870 – Page
1
If the adoption worker determines that the prospective adoptive
family should not be recommended for consent, the prospective
adoptive family must be informed and provided with a summary
of the factors that were considered in the decision.
One of three Adoptive family evaluations reviewed did not have documentation that
the agency provided a written report involving the denial recommendation of
adoption.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019.
DHHS Policy Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports
ADM 330 –Page
1
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress reports
using the DHHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress Report. The
adoption worker must have at least one face-to-face contact
with the child during each quarter prior to the adoption
supervision period for the purpose of completing the DHHS-614.
The child assessment may serve as the initial quarterly report if
it is completed within the required quarterly reporting period and
attached to the DHHS-614 form.
13

One of four Adoption Assessment/Placement case files reviewed did not have the
quarterly adoption progress report completed in the required time frame. The report
covered December 2019, January 2020 and February 2020; however, the report
was dated April 14, 2020.
This is a repeat citation from the 2019 annual licensing inspection for which a
CAP was approved on 8/30/2019.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
 The agency was not consistent in their coding of information uploaded into the
MiSACWIS system. This was discussed and the agency will develop a method of
providing over-site to ensure that information is coded in a consistent way.
 The agency was not consistent in having the case managers check the
appropriate items when entering social work contacts. Several times, it was
discovered that the case manager did not check the appropriate items for the
action that took place. The agency agreed to develop a system of over-site to
ensure that consistently is occurring.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 It was suggested to the agency that they develop a system of compliance to
ensure that all information is being uploaded as required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. This CAP was in response to their Annual
Licensing inspection for 2019.
Interviews with staff indicate that they are following the agency’s policy/procedure for
the current situation with COVID-19. All staff interviewed report still making contact
with the youth and caregivers in their program. Staff also report feeling supported by
the administration.
VII. SAFETY ALERTS:
There were no safety alerts during this period under review.
14

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
5/12/2020
________________________________________
Paul Fatato Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 18, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
15
